body:
Envy indicates resentment. I do not envy the rich. 

There are things about their lifestyle I wish I had for myself, but that's a goal. If you spend all your time angry about what you don't have instead of working to earn it, you'll always be angry with nothing.

Edit: apparently I read envy instead of admire, but I guess the answer is still relevant.

body:
I respect wealthy people who worked their way up to their current wealthy status.

I look at success (including financial success) like a Martial Arts belt system. 

Say "Bob" was born in a family of Ninjas. Bob was handed a black belt the moment he was born. He has no idea what it takes to earn a black belt, nor does he have the skill and discipline that people develop while working toward a black belt. Most importantly to me, Bob has been robbed of the feeling of working your way up. 

Say Bob decides that he needs to show the rest of the world how this Martial Arts shit is done. Bob switches styles and starts at a different school. On day one, Bob has his ass handed to him by an Orange Belt. Bob may officially be recognized as a Black Belt but he has absolutely no actual skill or discipline. He's out of his element.

Likewise, people who never experience that "just get by" or "Paycheck to Paycheck" lifestyle would have no idea how to navigate that lifestyle.

I admire wealthy people who earned their way there and didn't let their success get to their heads.

body:
My ex-'s uncle was a self-made multi-millionaire. Worst human I've ever had the displeasure of knowing. Total piece of shit. Lied, and cheated (business associates and his wife), stole, screwed people over for a dime. Drove his wife insane, and had her locked up in a mental institution that pumped her full of drugs that made her more insane, took her children away from her and left her penniless and she eventually put a gun to her head. All 3 of this kids are total pieces of shit. He used to hang out with Greek mafia because he thought it made him "cool" to play poker with them, and if he wasn't laundering money I'd be extremely surprised. If I saw him laying in a ditch on fire, I wouldn't piss on him to put him out. 

So, yeah....No. Mostly I hold rich people in utter contempt. I work with rich people all day. For the most part they're completely divorced from reality, entitled, arrogant, a lot of the time ignorant, and pretty much assholes to everyone--even each other. I mean, you're like 85 and you're still talking about other people behind their back like this is high school and you're the Mean Girls. If you're not a mature, kind adult at 85, i don't think there's much hope for you

body:
Increasingly not so. I became a libertarian a few years ago and the mainstream line of economic growth above all else, corporate praising, billionnaire worshipping, social progressivism at all costs and complete lack of morale (i'm looking at you Reason) now repulses me. I diverge, but seeing all entrepreneurs and wealthy people as heroes is despicable. 
Mainstream libertarians are as bluepilled and materialistic as commies often are, they're just not jealous in the heinous way.

Analyzing super rich people, I do not find many of them remotely admirable. They are very often absolute pricks, control freaks and genuinely greedy in a bad way. 

I used to fantasize about a big house, expensive watches and a 6 figure salary. Cant say I achieved all of this before snapping (thank god), but a Rolex did nothing. Chasing money, social status and materialism is a scam. Being self reliant, independent and not having to care about other people is better, and hanging out with rich people is not often very rewarding. They're often dicks.


Sorry for the rant, but in short no. I absolutely do not envy their wealth, many of them are infinitely more reliant on the "system" and are ironically less free than me. Among the wealthiest are mostly just corrupt pieces of shit, dishonest manipulators, talentless heirs/nepotists who did nothing to deserve it, and of course the commies could come for them and I wouldnt move, but the real entrepreneurs who at least deserve their money are often huge dicks who I have not much empathy for either. Very few from the top of my head make exceptions like Peter Thiel, Roger Ver and that Chamitsmth guy from Sri Lanka

/schizo rant over

body:
Some. Honestly I've done a lot of work for "wealthy people" and often find them to be the cheapest, most complainy clients to have. The theory is they didn't get rich by spending money and are generally adverse to the act - they'll find something to knock the price down and usually pay late.

Usually wealthy people who you don't know are really wealthy are the best. I know another guy who has to make it known that he's sending his blue swede shoes back to the cobbler in New York City to be re-soled and "oh man, it's gonna cost me like $800" or he'll complain about how he had to buy all of his grand daughters new Ugg boots at $300 each meanwhile he's in an office where people are making $15 an hour - that's bad taste and really douchey.

So... rich people are just like other people, and a lot of people are cunts.

body: I used to admire them. When I first read Atlas Shrugged I thought it was great and admired them more. The longer I have worked and the more I have seen how poorly leaders perform the more disillusioned I became. Then I started learning of the dirty tactics that the wealthiest businesses of the past and present have used to become the best. I now kind of loathe the richest among us unless it is someone I personally know to be of good character.
body_html: I used to admire them. When I first read Atlas Shrugged I thought it was great and admired them more. The longer I have worked and the more I have seen how poorly leaders perform the more disillusioned I became. Then I started learning of the dirty tactics that the wealthiest businesses of the past and present have used to become the best. I now kind of loathe the richest among us unless it is someone I personally know to be of good character.

body:
Yes! I agree. Many wealthy people have done bad things that I couldn't live with in order to gain their wealth. No thanks. Others have made choices, sacrificed and worked harder than I have chosen to inorder to achieve it- i admire the hard work, but often times don't find their sacrifices worth it, which is sad. I don't begrudge them what they have, it is about choices. 
My husband and I have 2 businesses that mean something to us, we are not wealthy, but we do work that we feel is important (I opened my own high school in order to teach content and methods that make sense, not public school shit). I took home almost zero dollars. 
Hubby is creating a solution to help us take better care of our public parks, and it is just noe turning a profit. We know and admire more people in our shoes- hard working, innovative, invested, passionate people doing what they feel is important. Some will make real money in their pursuits, but most of us wont- and thats ok. 
Those are traits to be admired.

body:
I started with a Biblical understanding that wealth was a spiritual danger, and that's how I interpreted certain wealthy people I saw (I thought the money they had enabled them to be more evil and they chose to be more evil), so I did not admire wealthy people but in a sense pitied them

But I have also seen harms of poverty and I do not admire the condition of the poor either but in a sense pitied their struggle

I think we want to have a mean between the extremes, of having enough to not be in poverty but of not having so much wealth that it is bad for us, but with perhaps erring to the side of poverty if we are particularly seeking after spiritual perfection:

> But having food, and wherewith to be covered, with these we are content. (1 Timothy 6:8)

(food and clothes, or necessities, is enough)

> Give me neither beggary, nor riches: give me only the necessaries of life (Proverbs 30:8)

(not to be poor or rich, but to have what you need, is enough)

body:
As an example, I watched a show about adventure racing a while ago. nobody there was a slouch, but one team had this this woman who was raising four kids with her husband, had done a PhD, managed two companies as CEO, and here she was competing in crazy endurance contests for fun. She was super fit, spoke three languages, and gave every impression of having it all under control. 

I'm in okay-ish shape with a good career and a decent educational background, but her shit is just on another level.

I don't know if she was like 9-to-11-figures super rich, but I'd be shocked if she wasn't at or near double digit millions. Regular-ass people don't have that list of accomplishments & a spare  couple weeks to run around Bali in lycra.

There are other rich people who I look at and think, yeah you did some cool shit, but you're really just a business executive and I can probably do it as well or better.

body:
I admire people that are kind and thoughtful. Wealth is not a criterion for me.

As for what my prejudices are for wealthy people, I believe that crappy people and also kind people can acquire wealth. (No matter if they got it 'cause of their abilities, hard work, luck or inheritance.) I've met wealthy people that are very well-meaning and kind.

But the majority of wealthy people most probably belong in the crappy group, imo. The reason is that wealth, social status, success and materialism attract mostly the selfish and vain, the "crappy" ones. So it basically comes down to statistics: The crappy ones are most likely to put more effort in acquiring wealth than the "kind" ones. So you'll find a greater percentage of "crappy" people in the wealthy group than in the general population. But I won't be surprised if I see a very kind person being very wealthy. It's only a statistical probability.

PS. Great question.

body:
I find the projection of success, ie: prosperity, and monitary wealth to be an oxymoron. To be more specific, I have never met a truly financially wealthy person to be happy. Ill define happy as content, joyful or untroubled. In the example you indicate, ie:  the impressive woman, I wonder if your impression is contrary to my experience. 

That stated, its easy to be misled by comparisons. Ill use golf as my example. In my game, its just me doing better every time I go out. Its me watching a pro golfer or a partner I play with.  Its  the beauty and grace of his or her game. I dont compete with anyone I play, I find I share it, the whole experience of the day. Im not looking for a financial gain. So, it seems to me one must make the determination as to what is the objective?  Is it the journey, is it the financial gain, or is it some other component of ones definition of success?

parent.body:
As an example, I watched a show about adventure racing a while ago. nobody there was a slouch, but one team had this this woman who was raising four kids with her husband, had done a PhD, managed two companies as CEO, and here she was competing in crazy endurance contests for fun. She was super fit, spoke three languages, and gave every impression of having it all under control. 

I'm in okay-ish shape with a good career and a decent educational background, but her shit is just on another level.

I don't know if she was like 9-to-11-figures super rich, but I'd be shocked if she wasn't at or near double digit millions. Regular-ass people don't have that list of accomplishments & a spare  couple weeks to run around Bali in lycra.

There are other rich people who I look at and think, yeah you did some cool shit, but you're really just a business executive and I can probably do it as well or better.

He made a bunch of money and used it to build a spaceship. If that's not fun, I can't help you.

body:
Do you know Richard Branson? Go ahead and project he is happy. Thats YOUR schtick.  I would suggest more often than not extreme financial wealth does not deliver what you think it does. You think its about BUILDING businesses to "share" stuff. You think he has made a bunch of money and used it to build a spaceship. Often, the truth is vastly different. That is my personal observation. Life is different than the spin given by Time magazine, Oprah Winfrey, or any of the other spin masters including Mr. Bransons marketing team. Its like Hollywood Libertopian. This fame and lifestyle is just that, a Hollywood myth. 

Many people suggest that the public "needs" the lie that money literally buys everything/anything of true value. They portray people like Mr. Branson as this handsome, financially wealthy globe trotter everyone is dying to do business with. The reality is the piece is "planted" to attract investors. Mr. Branson (or someone like Mr. Branson) has no skin in the game at all. He is a front man. Often a very unhappy front man in struggle on many levels. 

So, my point is simply this: Beware of the very carefully scripted "picture" of success. From what I have seen (and experienced) Id rather be with you and your family. This, because I can tell you are real.

body: Envy doesn't always indicate resentment. I'm extremely envious of a particular online acquaintance because she has literally exactly the ideal life I've always wanted myself but could never even get near. I've sometimes legit wondered if I'm a mistake or an error attached to this person somehow, that's how precise it is. It makes me hate myself and it makes me despise the world for being so unfair. But not the person I'm envying, as it's neither of our faults.

parent.body:
Envy indicates resentment. I do not envy the rich. 

There are things about their lifestyle I wish I had for myself, but that's a goal. If you spend all your time angry about what you don't have instead of working to earn it, you'll always be angry with nothing.

Edit: apparently I read envy instead of admire, but I guess the answer is still relevant.

parent.body: Envy doesn't always indicate resentment. I'm extremely envious of a particular online acquaintance because she has literally exactly the ideal life I've always wanted myself but could never even get near. I've sometimes legit wondered if I'm a mistake or an error attached to this person somehow, that's how precise it is. It makes me hate myself and it makes me despise the world for being so unfair. But not the person I'm envying, as it's neither of our faults.
